content:
15, 2014
												I Loved this game....  Up untill a week ago.  (No play time on steam, played through their client because steam was not working right.  You can download their client directly from www.panzar.us)The last patch made the game 100% pay to win.If you dont plan on shoveling out loads of cash to buy gear for each level range Im sorry to say, this game is not for you.Sure it needed some balance changes but overall the gameplay was very engaging and a lot of fun.  However, the crafting system needed a lot of work.  By level 15 it was taking me 50+ (5-20 minute games)  to get the components to craft the easiest pieces of my level tier gear.   The harder ones or "epic" items were clearly our of my range, needing almost 10x the ingrediants of their lesser version.  I didnt mind though.  I would just craft them as I played....However now.  If you want to craft an item you must collect almost 150% more materials and now have a 50% to successfully craft the item(which you can increase to 80% chance by sacraficing vital skill points better used elsewhere). Thats a 50% chance to destroy all the materials you spent days gathering (if you play a lot)Of course you could pay....  paying has 100% chance of success. I really hope they change this fatal error.

content:
er 3, 2013
												The good : The gameplay is solid, the classes are all varied and each has their own weakness and strength.  Unlike many multiplayer games, this game is very reliant on team-work.  If your team isn't working together efficiently, you aren't going to win.  Plain and simple.  This is a game that I feel can truely be called a "MOBA" (Multiplayer Online Battle Arena), as opposed to games like League of Legends or Dota 2.  The variety of maps and gameplay modes put it into the higher tier of online gaming.  Something like 24 maps and 6 gameplay modes will give you hours of enjoyment.  While it might look hectic in videos and screenshots, after a few matches youll adjust and be able to spot enemies from allies easily.   The game runs smooth, and looks great in action at max settings.  There are some customization options with being able to paint all your gear different colors as well as some facials features like different hair styles, but that's where the downfall of the game begins.The bad :The way this game makes it's money feels very cheap.  Allow me to explain.  At the end of each match you are given X amount of materials like linen or gold nuggets or bark.  The amount you are given is based on your overall points in the match, which materials you are given is completely random.  As you level up, you are able to craft various sets of gear that add substantial stats to your character like + hp or +mastery (mastery being the attribute that increases the power your special abilities).  At first it seems great.  Level 4 opens up and it takes roughly a half hour to craft each of the handful of pieces available.  But that's where things start to suffer.  By the time you reach the max level (currently 20 on EU/NA servers) you are looking at spending, quite literally, WEEKS crafting the item sets.  The amount of materials it takes to create the top level gear is ridiculous.  So not only will you spend weeks grinding the materials, but you'll also wait additional days/weeks to actually craft the gear.  The ugly : In itself, this wouldn't be so bad.  Tweak a few numbers here and there and it would be no biggy.  But this is where the cash shop comes in.  You can flat out buy the same armor sets people will spend weeks grinding/crafting out in a matter of seconds.  While this game may not seem like it's pay to win at the early levels, once you hit the max level I assure you it comes down to two tiers of players.  Those that drop 40$ or so to get the best gear, and those that will spend weeks getting decimated while crafting it themselves.Many fans of the game will claim that "skill owns gear" in this game, and they are partially correct.  Skill plays a major role in this game.  If you cannot block properly or do not learn the telegraphs of specific moves, you are going to get creamed.  However, at a certain point skill becomes a moot point when you're attacking someone at the same level and same class yet he has 2x your health and does 2x your damage simply because he decided to outright buy the gear rather than grind and craft it.This is a very poorly thought out system and screams cash grab.  Combine this horrid use of a cash shop with the fact that the game (nearly a year after it's Russian release) is still riddled with game debilitating and breaking bugs and it quickly becomes a chore.  I have had sessions where within 2 hours of playing I crashed to the desktop nearly a dozen times.  Add to the fact that just recently it seems either their servers got hacked and it's simply a no go.Final thoughts :This game has amazing potential.  The actual gameplay is very fun, but everything else about it is bad.  Would I continue to play it if they hammered out all the major bugs and reworked the cash shop?  Absolutely.  But I cannot realistically see that happening anytime in the future.It's worth a try if you want to see what a real MOBA should play like, but not much more than that.  Gameplay I give it a 8/10.  Everything else I give it a 2/10.

content:
r 14, 2014
												To be honest, this game looks and plays very well. It has some the most visualy impressive graphics i've probably ever seen in a free to play game. But while it looks pretty and all, the game's main issue is that it's a straight up money grubbing pay to win game. At first, the match ups are fair and, for the most part, well balanced. Everyone has an equel chance to kill and be killed. Sadly this can only be said about the early matches. After you get settled into the game and you think that things are going to be progressing at a fairly paced rate, like a good game should, you start getting matched up with people that are WAY stonger you simply because they invested some real money into their character. They get an enormous advantage over anyone who didn't pay for the in-game currency and ultimatly win. And when they win they win HARD! You'd initially think to yourself "Eh, maybe it won't happen too often" or "its not that bad" to try to make yourself feel better about your horible defeat. Then match after match, loss after loss you realize that it's a constant and reaccurring cycle that completely frustrates and irritates you to the point of hair loss. The only way to even have a remote chance to beat those players are if you happen to have one of those pay to win players on your team or you succumb to the pressure and cough up the dough. Either way you get screwed!Though this next problem might not seem very big, it actually is the very root of the pay to win problem. That honor goes undoubtedly to the dreaded item creation system. This game's creation system is one of the most sneaky and insulting kick to the groin! To create an item you must not only get a bunch of materials that are hard to come by,  you must also have a ton of money to then buy the item. In addition to having to buy the items at a ridiculously high price, you also gain a ridiculously low amount of money from battles which makes paying for items a really daunting task. And if you think that they could'nt possibly make it any worse you are sorely mistaken. It then gives you a wait period for your item to be made. And this could last for several hours to even days to recive the item you have worked tirelessly to get. The game's creators purposly designed it like this to push players to buy their in-game currency. Sure it rewards the ones that purchase the in-game currency, but they completly neglect and almost punish the players that didn't want to purchase anything and simply wanted to play a good free game. It can be argued that in a buisiness stand point a free to play game has to make some profit somehow. Which is very much true. But they fail to realize that it should be left as an option for the player to choose from without the fear of facing an unfair advantage. Many thriving free to play companies do this, and they have some of the most happy and loyal fanbases along with more than enough money to keep afloat (a good example of that is Team Fortress 2). This creation system takes away what makes the game fun for EVERYONE and just serves as something that stops it from reaching it's full potential.But of corse, credit has to be given to where credit is due. Despite it being a money grubbing machine, the combat is really well done and diverse (this is the potential i was talking about earlier). Each class has their own unique abilities and play styles. They all play smoothly when in combat and each of them have an important role to fill in the team. Wether you're the support or the tank, each one is equally just as vital to achieve victory. The character designs are very unique and interesting enough to keep you entertained for a while. The amount of attention put into the graphics is fenominal! The max graphics settings looks fantastic with the amount of detail put into the characters and battlegrounds. When it comes to gameplay and graphics this game passes with flying colors.Panzar is one of those games that i personally would not recommend, but if you think that you can get passed all of it's outragous problems or you plan to spend money on this game then go right ahead. play and enjoy this game as much as you possibly can. =)

												Prior to the latest update I used to love this game.  It has great graphics and is extremely engaging.  It used to have a good battle and loot system, and was reasonably fair in terms of the offered monetary VIP options.  However, the 08/11/14 latest update took all the fun out of this game. The players are now very obviously squeezed for cash.  In my opinion this radical change will not only disappoint and drive away the dedicated players that have already put hours (and money) into this game, but will also scare off new potential players.Unless Panzar reverts back to its pre-update stage, it will not continue for long.

content:
er 25, 2013
												It's a Team Based PVP oriented game set up in a typical F2P format where players can grind to earn what they want or simply pay for it.  The cash shop sells a variety of items such as cosmetics, level ups, crafting materials & potions.  Currently the only game modes available are Capture Point, King of The Hill & Domination.  There is a lack of a server list & choice of game mode so you won't know what game mode or map you'll be getting into until you start playing.  Several different maps are available & range from small, medium & large & all hold up to 20 players or 10v10.There are 8 Classes Available Including: Warrior, Tank, Rogue, Healer, 2 Engineers, & 2 Mages.The warrior is just that.  A hard hitting force to be reckonded with.  While the tank hits almost as hard, he can also absorb a substantial amount of damage compared to his counterpart.  The Rogue (Or Inquisitor as this game calls it) is a stealthy assassin type of character that does bonus damage when behind his target.  The Healer is just that, & is almost required to win games. The engineers play both as support & damage roles by building useful tools for themselves & allies to use such as teleports, mortars & turrets.  The Ice mage is mostly a support role, freezing enemies so others can destroy them but can also do damage when she needs to.  The fire mage plays as the main ranged damage dealer, & is very weak at close range.Each class has their own variety of moves & gains more as they level up VIA the skill trees.  There are 30 levels total & 30 talents in each skill tree.There is also a crafting system, while it is fairly simple can be a tad frustrating if you don't plan on paying for bonuses.  Materials are given randomly after each game & getting what you need for a particular item can become time consuming.  You do gain additional materials based on your overall performance & if you win a game.  You can also trade materials you don't need for ones that you do.  After gaining enough items it's a simple process of clicking a few buttons & waiting for the item to be made.  Higher level items take longer to produce.  The items crafted go into a queue & you can play games or simply turn the game off while it's produced.  If you buy a booster you can craft more items at once & gain more materials from matches.  The crafting is set up to 3 catagories: Equipment, Support Items such as potions or gems & higher ranking materials.The graphics in the game range from down right beautiful, to slightly cartoony.  You may want to take a moment to admire the craftmanship that went into each level.  Some levels look better than others & range from a lush forest scenery to that of desert ruins & run down fortresses.  The character models can be compared to those in World of Warcraft as being fairly cartoony but enjoyable to watch.  Animations are a bit choppy at times but feel good overall when playing the game.The game feels unfinished, however.  There are bugs, balancing issues, & crashes.  There is also a cursor issue where it will stay on your screen even during combat.  While this is annoying, if you angle your camera properly it can be less so.  There are also some performance problems, long load times & occasional slowdown.  My machine isn't the most powerful, mind you.  As with any online game nowadays we can probably expect most of these issues to be resolved in future patches & updates.The sound in the game is... In progress.  You know how in other games when you slash your foe you hear some sort of impact sound?  Well this game doesn't have that.  At least, not yet.  It becomes difficult at first to know if your hits are even connecting to your target.  Some classes attacks have impact sounds, others do not.  I do not know if this is meant to be intentional or if it is simply unfinished in the sound department. The music is fairly generic as well & is forgettable.  Sound effects are also generic & not really satisfying but they get the job done. Overall the game is fun & is free so it's probably worth your time to at least try it out.A good game.

content:
2014
												Panzar is very sharp and detailed, above and beyond for a free to play game. This is what lured me into trying it in the first place, it looked so incredibly awesome I couldn't believe it.Easy to learn, giving you only several abilities to deal with at a time, while also being unique in its classes and fun to hop into. Being a PvP game, they have recently gone into the alpha for a PvE gametype where you need to race the clock and capture points and defeat bosses, while trying not to wipe the group. I recommend trying it out, allowing you to learn the class you wish to play and its abilities.Now, lets talk about the actual gameplay. Aside from the pay to win, the game features bland combat that is dominated primarily by two classes, the Gunner and the Tank. These two can pound out insane amounts of damage while easily avoiding death which makes life harder for everyone playing the other 5 or so classes. Matchmaking is also pretty slow, as it has a very small player base, mostly russian. On Steam, it seems to peak around 400-500 people. If you happen to get into a game, make sure you stay the whole time and immediately enter the queue for another game, as you will get in faster, likely with several of the people from the previous match.Unless you play as tank or berserker, you will die pretty quickly, so the game can be slow for new players trying to understand how the game works and can discourage people from bothering at all. The game is also pretty glitchy, sometimes trapping you in walls and other bulges or cliffs in the map. I have noticed it most when playing Gunner and trying to place turrets beside cliffs or rocks, making it collide with the environment.Last but certainly not least is the pay to win. People will argue and say its "pay to progress" and I am very well aware of this term and what it means, but this game forces you to grind so long for so little reward that to have the best armour in the game requires you to do two things, play either 200-300 hours or pay a simple 35$ (around that, its in euros) and have enough of the in game currency to buy you everything you need to destroy everything in sight.It's free and the graphics are nuts, if you have an hour or two and you're bored, give it a go.Personal Rating: 2.5/5

content:
18, 2014
												A MOBA, somewhat Indie, and free to play. Sounds good, is good.Starting UpThe tutorial is ok, but a bit long for what it teaches you. Most is learning by doing. Important things like what's the HUD, how does the character screen work and such is a bit tricky to find out at first, but possible. Hints in loading screens give you well chosen information about the game and fills up the incomplete tutorial to a fullfilling knowledge about how things work.First Gameplays (Lvl <10)Well, talking about how people play in lowlevel, it's just like in a kindergarten, trying things out a bit. But that's ok, I mean you gotta see the arenas first, see other classes, maybe try out a skill - that's exactly what you need at that point. You'll learn how your skills work and what class does how much damage and so on. So feel free to be a kindergarten kid yourself ;)Later Gameplays (Lvl 10-30)Here things start to get a bit complicated. You'll be put into games against better geared players, or players with a higher level and therefore they have more skills available. Some of the players are leveling a twink, and actually know how to play and suceed by experience. And you are in the mid of this, neither having gear, nor skills, nor gameplay experience. This may seem frustrating. This may be one reason why lots of people give negative comments after 2-3 hours of gameplay. However, this is how you learn to play. One guy in the forum said it pretty well, although it's a bit mean: Put out your diapers, level up, make 2-3 new pieces of gear, and observe why you die and do next time better - then you are the one farming the others, instead of getting farmed. It's important just to give the game a chance here and not stop instantly. Even if you loose 5 games in a row, the next day you win 5 games in a row.Engame 1 (Lvl 30 but no gear yet)Here you'll probably gonna say, that you need freaking ages to get your best tier gear ready, and that they only want you to buy that gear. However, the match maker sees that you are not fully geared yet and puts you in corresponding games. So be happy to have something to achieve in the game: Get your gear ready. I mean Hearthstone all golden heros and all heros maxlevel take longer than this here. As you get your ressources together, you're continuing to learn how to play and will slowly notice, that there are nice combos within characters, you'll notice some kind of team work may be good... :O Endgame 2 (Lvl 30 full gear)Seems pretty balanced inbetween classes and stuff. The single problem is that the matchmaker may try to balance out the teams, but often it happens that you eithr farm the other team, or your team is getting farmed. And that kinda sucks. Tight matches aren't happening so often, but are exactly the most fun ones. Cool is though, that lots of people leave the match when you get farmed, and new ones join, and this repeats until both teams are plus minus equally strong.For the play itself, it's pretty awesome. You should find some friends, team up and play together. Said in last paragraph, teamplay is important and makes fun. For example, the fire witch shoots a freezing frost witch into the air, stopping her from her action, while the friendly frost witch can now easily freeze the enemy frost witch. Or a Dwarf puts bear traps on a spot, and a tank pulls an enemy onto those traps, killing him instantly. There are tons of combos like these, and I like the versatility given into the game by those combos.Another important point is that basically every skill can be countered by the enemy team. E.g. the freezing of a frost witch can be countered by: Fire witch shooting up, Inquisitor dusting you, Paladin unfreeze, Zerk 'sucker punches', Tank shield, Sapper steam hammer, and Gunner... guess he just kills the Witch. Poor Ice Witch...  I guess that's the reason they are always so mad ^^. However, so can the ice witch basically counter every class and every action by freezing them. The question will be, who does his job better? Who has the better team support? And it may be these questions, that are defining the gameplay. Anyway. I love the gameplay.GraphicsCry 3, ♥♥♥♥♥♥ awesome.SoundVery lovely made, orchestral epic style, some really nice tracks in there. Like it.Sound effectsSound pretty good, although Panzar probably didn't invest much in them (guess all computer generated). But quite ok for that."Trivia" / Things to knowA big aspect is the fun put into the game. E.g. there is an emote for the Orc, laughing like hell and falling on his back. You will laugh yourself when seeing this first time. Or the Golem, that repairs gunner's and sapper's structures, is made so stupidly, that it's simply pure fun to watch that guy. There are tons such little funny details, that are very cute.CommunityLots of kids in public chat, as usual. But it's ok. On the forums, it goes quite polite and more or less educated, the community holds together against stupid patches, and the devs listen normally. There is a weekly livestream by the community manager, where some news and stuff are told, pretty cool. Also if you put a question or a report onto the forum, they are usually quickly answered. Guys that are online on a daily basis will meet each other in the matches repeatedly and therefore know each other by time, getting easy friends this way.TournamentsAre weekly and very fun and the biggest part in the endgame. Very good concept. So find a clan, and participate ;)P2WAll you get by paying is either a time advantage, or you get pretty colors, emotes, and so on. But: Everything that is game relevant (gear, skills, useable items, and so on) are achieveable without money. Therefore it's theoretically not pay to win.The matchmaker defines a 'battle value' for you, and puts you in matches where people have more or less the same battle value. What gear you wear plays a significant role for the battle value. Therefore, all players in your game have around similar gear as you. So there is not even a need to buy gear, since if you do, your value increases, therefore your enemies will also be better. All you can do by money is just speeding up the whole process of reaching full gear.Of course in the endgame, you wanna keep up with your useable items, that run for a limited time. So you need to play quite a bit for that, so you can recreate your amulets every week. That works more or less well as long as you play regularly, but latest patches made it impossible to keep up with certain time-limited gear. P2W or F2P, as in any game that is announced as F2P, it's worth a discussion.Lot's of people write here in their reviews it's p2w. But sorry, it's not that simple. If you suck you suck, you suck with low gear (fighting against low gear due to battle value and matchmaker), and you'll still suck when you buy the best gear (fighting against the best gear).Overall:Very awesome game and recommended, at least give it a try. I mean it's f2p, so nothing to loose ;)

ry 3, 2014
												Do you like theme park PvP? Good, this game is theme park PvP without the rest of the theme park. The game has a decent crafting system and for the most part a friendly community. It is 100% team work. If you are not doing your part you will lose.This is some of the most epic PvP I personally have ever done. I reccomend this game to anyone who enjoys hardcore pvp.The only thing i dislike is waiting times in que for matches.As the player base grows I'm sure that will change. I noticed a few people said this game is "Pay to win". I disagree, I have not put a dime into this game. I have only used the crafting and enhancement systems to upgrade. I have been extremely competitive. If this game is "Pay to win" then so is RIFT, LOTRO and other F2P models with cash shops. It offers very similar things that those games offer in their cash shops. Reviews are opinions. We know what opinions are like. We also know everybody has one. So, try it out and decide for yourself. Look for the clan Team USA. They are a friendly, English speaking clan that will help you to understand the game. This game is in development. It is not 100% polished but game devs are working on it. There are new patches with fixes and new content regularly. Oh and its FREE!!!

content:
r 13, 2014
												This game seemed to have a lot going for it.  The combat and classes are interesting, the crafting system is a grind but manageable, and it is actually fun to play.  However, it has some keyboard smashing features that just aren't fixable:1.  Long queue times.  For a MOBA, you'd expect multiple games to be starting every minute for every level range.  That doesn't seem to be the case in this game, with queue times approaching 20 minutes or more for a single game sometimes.  And there is little transparency in the matchmaking process, no indication that games are forming, completing, or that players are even queued.  2. Everyone on your team is Russian.  They don't understand you, you don't understand them.  It makes a team based game very difficult.  You may as well remove voice chat, which doesn't really work anyway.3. Lack of new player information available.  The English wiki is unfinished, there is little information on the English forums, there is little information provided in the game, and the tutorial is so uninformative and restrictive that it's a chore just to finish it.4. Everyone seems to be terrible at this game.  I've played less than 10 hours and not past level 5 with a single class and I have topped the board with all of them at least once.  How hard is it to stand on the circle?  I chalk this one up to the previous two bullet points: lack of communication and in-game help.Overall, it's a fun game that seems to be failing simply due to a lack of interest from US players.  If there were language based games, that alone would solve 3 of the 4 problems I have with this game, but then I'd still be sitting in the queue, waiting to actually play it.

er 3, 2013
												No, It's not a Warhammer game, surprisingly. This Russian made Online Battle game is pretty awesome. Going in, you need to know that the voice acting and tutorial level is painfully terrible. Try to suffer through it so that you get the free rewards from it and learn the basics of battle though. After that, a solid but rough game awaits you. It is very fun and has a robust action combat system with LMB attacks and RMB power attacks, as well as special attacks/abilities on the number keys. There's also a loot drop system after every fight that will give you resources to build more armor and weapons for your character, as well as get XP for unlocking new abilities. There is some extreme balancing and you might feel like the sneak attacks from the Stealth character are cheap... until the big 2-handed club wielding Orc rolls up and one shots that guy for you. Anyway, try it out, it's pretty fun, but keep in mind it's a Russian game that is rough around the edges and still getting updated regularly.

er 9, 2013
												I just went through some of the reviews on the community page and noticed everyone who gave it a bad review played it for less than an hour.  Sure this game has a few hiccups now but I believe it could become a great game in the not too distant future.I'll start with what I don't like.  First bad thing I noticed was the game tends to crash.  However, after updating my graphics card, it started crashing much less frequently.  I also don't like that you can only form a group of three friends when joining a queue which makes it hard for me to invite more friends knowing i won't get to play with them all at once.  Even when I do have a full party (3 people) the matchmaking tends to be a little slow; especially when you're lvl 5 or higher.  Here's what I did like.  The graphics, first of all, are spectacular but that goes without saying since its cryengine.  When I played by myself i was a little lost but when I finally got some friends online I found it to be a very well put together team game.  Someone put it ealier it's kind of like Team Fortress and World of Warcraft had a baby.  A lot of people hail this as a pay to win but i see it more as a pay to progress faster game.  If anyone giving this a bad review would have played it longer than an hour they may have figured that out themselves.  I don't think i've ever run into an instance where I was fighting someone who out leveled or geared me to the point where they absolutely destroyed me.Like i said, it's without its issues now but I really do think this game could be fun if the community were to expand.

content:
15
												This game is a RPG MOBA. Not like League of Legends or DotA2, because of no tower/nexus defense mode: Panzar has a different variety of maps and mode, more like Overwatch.From capture the zone to assault, you'll find yourself in an incredible fantasy battle, fighting against orcs, elves, dwarves, and humans.You can choose between 8 (and all avaiable) classes, all well defined by their own races. It's a very frenetic game, and each class has its weight on fighting.PROS:- Well made game, i found no bugs at all (until now).- Variety of classes, each one has its pros and cons. None is stronger than another.- You have room both for indivual and team skill in fighting. It depends on you character's class.- Not an heavy game.- Each game takes from 2 to 10 minsCONS:- Very few people palying it: all in PVP and none in PVE- Because of this, you are matched with and against people of a much higher level than you.- Controls are quite hard- Half of the people playing this game is russian, and as so they won't speak english.- A BIT p2w, but only a bit. You can still play and have a lot of fun, but don't expect that you can unlock everything instantly.WHAT I'D LIKE PROGRAMMERS TO CHANGE:- Sometimes cast time requires too long, even for basic skills- Make a shorter training- Create 2 more classes: an archer (a REAL archer) and a priest (a buffer, not a healing templar: you could give him spells to buff elemental damage, speed, attack speed, cast time, Will over time...)VOTE: 8/10

												Great game - probably the best MOBA/RPG I've ever seen. Visually it's just awesome, new step in the evolution of free-to-play games. Concerning gameplay - well, here we have some tried-and-true approaches: four standard (to be honest not completely standard - JUST LOOK AT THOSE SCARY ELVES!) fantasy races, eight typical classes, several also typical play modes and a really great amount of different (but always picturesque) maps.Is it entertaining? Oh yeah - especially after level 4 or 5 when a player actually gets enough abilities to choose between them and starts using some strategy thinking instead of constant clicking. Then it becomes just more and more interesting.Can't understand all the fuss around its monetization system. If you don't want to buy smth in the game you can always craft it. The crafting takes some time but it's fair and sensible. NO unique items or any advantages for donaters.

content:
er 5, 2013
												This game is getting a really bad rap at the moment and i believe unfairly so, the reason i write this review is because many current reviews just don't have the play time under their belts to make a judgement or at least an accurate one.Lets cover the elephant in the room first.Free to play in todays gamer community is usually a very dirty word, conveying low quality and high prices in the long run via microtransactions and despite the fact that Panzar's main menu has many microtransaction advertisements overall they are not that intrusive. I personally have not seen anything in the game yet that a little hardwork and elbow grease won't get you. The game is not entirely dependant on microtransactions as many seem to believe possibly due to the main menu advertisements mentioned earlier. The game itself has a rich and diverse trading community with public and clan trades happening often due to easy management of resources and clear menus and social chat boxes, also in-game ability to trade resources without other players when the trading front looks bleak for example, say i wish to trade iron for wood but none of my friends are online at the time so i go to my resources menu, from here i can use the static trading system to trade 2 iron for 1 wood with no real  cash involved. Very simple very effective.Many people claim the game is pay to win for those of you unfamiliar with this term it usuallys confers that the games microtransaction market will allow you to purchase items to make you better than everyone. I'd like to go into a little depth about this, all the items i have seen so far including cosmetics are easily obtainable through a little work usually on par with your skill and level bracket purchasing things such as levels will push you up a bracket (For example your level 9 and buy your way to level 10, all this does is put you in with people the same level as you.). Things such as items, weapons and armour can also be bought with microtransactions but once again these things are easily obtainable in-game and make no real diffrence in combat and gameplay if you are semi competent.I have encountered no pay to win so far.Now onto the graphics and gameplay.Graphically beautiful and exciting with a wide range of effects enhancing the action and gameplay with a feeling of rich immersion. All of this is on par with all of todays lastest games.This Free to play game easily nets half of a £40/$45 price tag through sheer detail and attention which have quite clearly been lovingly crafted by the development teams.Gameplay wise its highly entertaining for all types of gamers with options for brute force, team meat shield, stealth, magic and steampunk style engineers each with their own skill trees and all highly focused around team progresion. While early on in the game many battles may just feels like capture and hold the point to win around lvel 3-5 you start to join assault and defend matches with moving landscapes and defenses. With these new additions to the gameplay comes more in-depth tactics which affect the entire game.This is the more positive side of the game and summary i'd like to just point out the perks of this game.-Free to play.-Character development and building is fun rewarding and easy.-At certain times of day they have bonus experience points for everyone, along with competitions and free giveaways.-A live and active competitive community with tournaments.-The game is graphically beautiful with visually pleasing landscapes and backgrounds..-Easy social menus and chat menus, with an intuative interface.-Controls and gameplay mechanics are easy to learn falling into the nice category of a minute to learn a lifetime to master with a rewarding learning curve.-Classes are balanced and quite fair. (I find many disagree with this, however they have to realise that a turret building dwarf is not going to take down a "squishy killer" beserker, you are not a one man army and you never will be in this game, win as a team or lose as a team thats your options.)Now as they say there's no smoke without fire and as such we should also address the issues with this game. This list is a lot shorter and i feel i don't have to go into much detail here as most of it is self explanatory but i will add some details for clarity.-With the recent release on Steam Panzar has sadly gained a large chunk of new players and while a minority of these players are polite, kind and courteous, many of the new players are immature and childish spamming chat rooms and trying hard to ruin games however a bright light is on the horizon as the Panzar forum response seems very positive in fixing this. Intrestingly most of this stops around 10Pm at night, i'l leave this up to you to figure out.- I think this really goes without saying but with all games especially online games there are bugs, but once again the Panzar team on the forums seem to be active in dealing with these issues fortunatly they are not to noticeable in game. An extra plus note here for those of you who have played many online games is that i have yet to hear of hackers or see them.- Not really a negative but for those of you who prefer games with everything at your disposal from the start this game does take a little time to unlock things with the crafting sytem being in realtime, however this does not stop you playing matches with things you are upgrading or making. Its is a time sink but name me one game that you've enjoyed that has not been one?Hopefully this covers most of the basic aspects of the games and allows you to have a perspective from both sides of the fence on the game now.Yours hoping you're having a great time -CPW-

er 26, 2013
												I've been playing Panzar for 8 months more or less. This F2P has great graphics, intense action, is fast paced (on high levels), well balanced, with already a growing community taking part in tournaments. You can craft all of the cash shop items with in game ressources, except colors for you gear and emotes. The waiting time to get in game can be quite long at late hours but the more people play the less you have to wait ;)There are a lot of mechanics to master and teamplay is essential.The gameplay may seem a bit slow at first but it's get faster and faster as the levels go up.There is already a weekly tournament with a crystal (the cash shop currency) prize pool to reward the 4 best teams involving many different clans. With the growing population, hopefully the devs will bring the game to it's full potential (unlocking level 30) to make the fights even greater !

number of helpful: 6 of 7 people (86%) found this review helpful
content:
ry 14, 2014
												Lets get this outta the way. Yes it has microtansactions, as a free to play game it is unavoidable. But I am so very glad to say that the 'gems'  are used mostly on optional things, like speeding up crafting or cosmetics.  Speeking of crafting, panzar has quite the heavy focus on gear.  At the end of every match you are given materials such as leather and ore and from those materials you use the forge to construct your armor and equipment.  The crafting takes time, hours even at the higher teir, but it keeps going even when you are not in game so it is easy enough to que somthing up and let it build overnight. Do not come into this thinking it is an MMORPG. Panzar has persistant characters yes, but the gameplay is broken into matches. This is where the biggest issue is most clear. Waiting times for matches are far to long, but in truth that is not the games fault, it is simply a lack of players. Part of the reason i write this review is to actually encourage new players to check this game out. It has a fun feel, the matches adveraging around 20-30 min make great use of ones time, and the actual gameplay can become very intense.   Over all, 8/10

content:
2016
												I ♥♥♥♥ing love this game. The combat system and mechanics feel unique. I am not really into games like Dota or LoL. I do enjoy smite, but this game is not in the same category as those games even though when you look for similar games to Panzar those always come up. The main problem with this game is playerbase. I started playing as an East Coast player in the morning around 8am to 1pm. I had no issues getting into either OnE and PoP games. I do prefer the PvE aspect it has different unique scenarios based on the map. It does have a limited PvE playlist, but it provided me with hours of great gameplay and I still am not bored. During my playtime it was 90% Russian players, which means that teamwork it based on playing together each game and getting used to no vocal or type communication. I did not find this to be a problem as I prefer this to having 12 yr olds tell me how they have had sex with my mother.  Although it's possible buried in the Russian gibberish in the chat pane she was mentioned. This game is kind of like TF2 MvM game mode on extreme difficulty. It is like this in the sense that you are required to work together to defeat the PvE content. Going off on your own pretty much means you are going to die a lot and waste everyone's time.Each class has great abilities that contribute to the team. This game offers very little in way of tutorials. Each character goes through the same boring tutorial and after the first time it does suck. You can choose to skip it, but you lose valuable buff items and having a level up which unlocks a skill point which would greatly hinder you in your first encounter. The other non wave based PvE encounters resemble a nice sized dungeon like you would encounter in games like WoW.You move through a linear map and complete objectives while battling a large number of enemies. You face a couple of mini boss like minions in a few sections then at the end you have a boss battle.There is a steep learning curve in this game. There are many environmental hazards and boss mechanics that you must learn to counter and avoid. Most of the time you learn the hard way. At times I felt like What The ♥♥♥♥! As I get gang ♥♥♥♥♥ by about 20 some mobs who chain stun me. This is something you learn to work around. If your team is useful and you're a tank like class they know to widdle the mobs you have aggro on down. There is a lot of kiting in this game at times that can get old if your team is useless. Otherwise it's fun being the center of attention and plowing into a ♥♥♥♥ ton of mobs.Anyway, if you are on the fence just give it a shot up until around level 10 so you can unlock some of the better skills. The gunner is a wicked class and really dishes out some well needed DPS.I suggest you check out steam charts to ensure that you are joining when there are over 100 ppl playing. I know the player's is very low, but this game is just too much fun to not give a chance. When I played in the morning during the week I waited less than 3 minutes to get into a game. HTH,-pdTN

content:
er 13, 2016
												Russian. To start off with you need to know that this is a Russian made game with Russian servers and Russian player base. Kk , In this 3rd person melee/shooter you choose out of 8 classes/races to kill and kill and kill . Mainly for capture and hold objective games. The maps are small and incourage close up brawls with points to capture also small, in witch you have to stand in them to count to/as capture. Sometimes you play attacker or defender and sometimes there is multiple of these capture points.  Regardless it always turns into a chaotic kill kill kill game. Out of the classes there are orcs as tank or bezerker, dwarfs as gunner or sappers, humans as paladins or inquisititors and elfs as fire or ice witches. The genders are locked and even though gear changes appearence, you need to buy with real money skin or appearence changes. There is in game gold and shards for these things and lots and lots of resource items. Resource items is what you need specific amount of such and such to craft items. Kinda like recipes. Craft gear for your character. You can then upgrade the gear with gold . The resource items you earn after battle along with experiance . Experiance like usual levels up your character in with you can go to the alter to upgrade or gain that characters class albilities or skills. Some are moves some are passive. Choose what your favorite playing style for your character is and go along like wise in the alter. Each class has many ablilities and skills that leave alot to custimization for what you want to be doing in game. The controls are simple basic RPG style and wont be hard to master. Just get to what you like or HOW you like killing and get to it.  The graphics are great with such a interesting and fun art style. Its what caught me first. It was the character design and the little detail on them ( like the designs on the orks boxers/pants ) along wih the simple things of the class symbols and the maps waterfalls and  sharp clusterphobic designs. Its very pleasing and catching. The music was as so too, with folky fantasy theme to it. Full of humor, from just the cut scenes and the tuturial that definantly puts it out there. The tutorial does cover quite a bit but leaves a lot for you to trial and error in a good way. You play a few games with help, before they throw you out to the real game.The only bummer is there is little USA player base. Finding a game can be hard and then in one, everyone speaks russian. Games can be PVP or PVE.  So level up your character to get better abilities and collecting resources to build better armor and get better to do some more killing!

content:
, 2014
												This is the second review I have written for Panzar... originally I played through a few PVE matches then uninstalled and decided to warn others about what I thought was a pile of junk.  Later that night I found myself wanting to play Panzar, so I had to give it another try.  Im glad I did... below is a quick review then a short do's and dont's list so you can survive until things get a bit easier...Panzar is a third person, action MMORPG with a MAJOR focus on PVP and a simple lobby/crafting/clan/social system.  It is true action, meaning you aim your melee and ranged skills/abilities much like a first person shooter...no tab targeting. It has 8 gender/race locked classes to choose from, ranging from tank to stealther.Crafting is more happenstance in Panzar than something you 'try' to do, as both PVP and PVE award crafting materials and experience. You also do not need to have all of the materials in order to begin crafting an item and may stop and move to another at any time, then resume. Clans do not serve much function other than supplying you with a group of people with whom to form groups. HOWEVER, the server is dominated by Russian speaking people so you will wish to join an english speaking clan ... just ask in general chat and ye shall receive.PROS:1. FUN gameplay in pve and pvp2. simple system, easy to understand and use3. no grinding or farming 4. limited pay to win 5. heavily emphasized team play (great when people do their JOB)CONS:1. Mostly russian speaking community that is impossible to communicate with (google translate can be used as a one way means to talk AT them but you cant copy and paste from Panzar's chatbar. 2. If you elect to level up in PVE the first 5 levels will be VERY difficult due to lack of ranged abilities in the party to combat the archers, inexperienced players you are forced to PUG with , and language barrier.3. Somewhat lacking in content overall, particularly in PVE but they are adding new things very slowly4. no interplayer trading of any kind (money, items, cash currency, NOTHING)5. HEAVILY emphasized team play (nightmarish when people dont do their JOB)

content:
er 1, 2013
												In all my years of gaming I've never played this type of game. I'm really, really enjoying it. Typically play for 8 or more hours at a time.  Of course, did the same with War Thunder, Shattered Horizon, The Stanley Parable, etc. I'm a marathon player; I burn the camo at both ends! Sure, it needs improvements. The game requires a patch immediately after installing it, but it downloads at 56K modem speeds! This isn't the first game that relies on a launcher to update a game, but 100MB taking 30 minutes to download is appalling! And having never played this kind of game I could have used better tutorials on crafting and why I should craft some things over others. And speaking of tutorials, 9 classes equals 9 identical tutorials if you want to earn a class point for each one. And you are forced to watch the same badly done cut-scenes over and over with no option to skip them. Those voices! UGG! Better to just skip the tutorials altogether and earn your first rank by playing a round or two.The game has various classes and after you get past rank 5 there's supposed to be only 2 of each class on each team, greatly extending the matchmaking wait significantly. But if the devs want to make money (and they do) they will find a way to reduce the wait times. Speaking of which, the money you can spend on this game is for actual improvements to your skills and equipment vs just cosmetic stuff. This can lead to a P2W mentality, but a lot of games survive regardless if they're still fun to play. It's certainly easier to rank up in this game than others I've played. War Thunder would take years to rank up all of your crews if you simply ground your way vs paying to upgrade, for instance. I've spend $85 on that game already!I'm not very good at reviewing games, so that's all the ramblings of a Christmas Crack Monkey you're going have to put up with for now. Bottom line, I highly recommend this game if you're looking for casual and addictive fun.

content:
er 27, 2013
												A fun game that requires teamwork. Some may say the game is P2W but I disagree. The statement (of P2W) is based soley on the ability that paying players can buy 'time.' Time that is required to level up and craft gear; gear that requires crafting time, and material (that is needed to craft) awarded by playing the game. Which will inevitabily set back a free player as they need to put a considerable amount of time for gear (comparable to World of Tanks). The statement is also really dependent on the extent of said advantage to a lesser geared player. It is obvious that better gear gives higher stats but the importance of gear comes into question. It is of my opinion that skill prevails overall with gear only being complementary. In fact, several players go naked into battle. (Some hoard their materials for higher level gear)Any other P2W argument couldn't fit in this game as anything achievable by a paying player (with exception of asethetics/animations that give no advantage) can be achieved by a free player; albeit slower as a free player. But as said in the previous paragraph, it could be seen as P2W since free players would have to essentially grind for their gear. Nevertheless, I still see skill prevailing overall; where teamwork is at the driving wheel as to which team will be victorious.Panzar's matchmaking generally takes the brunt of the criticism. There are many times where people would become frustrated with the matchmaking mechanic. Most of the frustration really comes to the wait times - but that cannot be helped because, sadly, Panzar doesn't have the population it deserves. The other is: some classes stacking on one team. Let's say, hypothetically, one team has more Orcs (Orcs are the frontline fighters) than the other team, and said team with more Orcs wins. People on the losing team would lay their lost solely because the winning team had more Orcs. This might seem correct but in another instance a team with more Orcs would lose. Having played many matches, I've seen many scenarios played out; and because of this, my perspective is strongly of the idea that the game is heavily dependent on the teamwork used via skill. Everything else jsut complements the players' abilities on either team; it really just comes down to the better team.Anyways! There are eight classes you can play which is a nice variety. Multiple unique maps, but the basis of every map is 'capture the point.' So far the maps can be classified as either 'stronghold: attack and defend' (which allow siege equipment to be used, cannons, ramps, shields); arena, where there is either 1 point where teams can fight over who holds the single point the most; and, attack defend (similar to stronghold, but with less points to cap, and less to no emphasis on siege equipment). The only con I see from this game is its low playerbase.

content:
y 21, 2014
												Simple design that is easy to play yet there is enough options with class selection and play style to make it fun. Its a micro transaction model but the cost, if you so choose, is not so much of a cash grab as other games. The game is third person perspective arena pvp in real time. You have goals such as hold points, or king of the hill. You generate victory points which are represented in various fashions. You can construct obstacles which add a strategic element to the map and diversity. Win or lose you get experience and items to "level up" your character to unlock more abilities that you choose so there is an element of character customization although due to balancing there are preferable tree paths to take than others. Taking less optimal paths does not seem to "gimp" your character terribly. Items gathered from matches have names that resemble raw material like "bark" or "iron" and such. These are used in a small crafting portion where you combine material and wait a set amount of time for the item to be made. Level 1 items take 6 minutes and change while level 4 took about an hour. As you get higher the time sink becomes greater. This is a way for the game to encourage you to purchase more gems to speed up the process. Don't want to craft at all? No problem. All gear that can be made can also be straight out purchased and forego the process all together. Bottom line? Its a fun game that is easy to get into and out of. Don't have much time? You can play a match for 20 minutes and log off. Its a lot of fun with friends. Also everything you can buy can also be crafted for free. The difference between buying and playing for free is simply time. If you don't care about getting less gold, less XP, less drops than someone who is paying then its no big deal. You can play for free and get everything the premium player who is paying except that it will simply take you longer. This is not a big deal because they make these games to make money. Its a business.

content:
er 4, 2013
												Been only playing it for a fews hours, and so far, I really like it. Only reason I haven't played it more is because I'm still more interested in AC4 and Batman AO. But those are both $60 value games, so it's unfair to compare with a F2P. Nonetheless it is Pay-to-win.  Contrary to what... alot of the reviewers are saying.  I have yet to find a game dominated repeatedly by a pay to win fanbase.  There are people with less hours than me on here claiming the oppisite, how can they do that? Were they really that unlucky? In the end, this game is free. It only takes about 5 hours or less to download, so it's worth a try.  I like the combat, the art, the leveling system.  Yes, pay to winners can get a big boost but they all die the same if you get em outnumbered which outnumbering happens on a regular back and forth basis, I like it..  But I've actually won more than I've lost.  Now there are only two ways this can happen.  1) There aren't as many pay to win players as others claim or 2) pay to win people are equally put on sperate teams so there is no big domination factor.  At least not on a constant re-occuring basis.  Seeing as how I see alot of half naked people like me running around, I'll go with 1.  If you are half naked, you are just starting.  Its beautiful, fun and free, like I said, it's worth a try.  Just have fun and dont put on your try hard pants right out of tutorial. I mean, it's a free to play.

												I kind of adore this game, it has the battlefield feel to it in that you're taking over points and what-not. And it also has set races/classes, the customiation leaves something to be desired. If you can take all that though and are looking for quick LoL type matches with orcs and dwarves I think there are lots worse than this game. I haven't dropped money on the game either, sure I'm not at end game but as it's going they try to match you with people at your skill level (battle effectiveness I think they call it) so while I may one day go vip just for the crafting part that gimps out for free players, is a solid choice for some time killing imo.

content:
er 27, 2013
												Worth a try at least for a few hours of a good casual fun. Hardcore gamers may have to put money down. What I liked: ----Combat:                      The combat is fluid and fast paced.   Every class seems to have a defined role that they are expected                                                 to play for the sake of synergy.   The teamplay doesn't look apparent at first, but after a few hours in you see how the better players coordinate. Tanks will shield allies behind them, Inquistors will assassinate the ranged targets etc.  It can feel a bit "weightless" at times however.---- Presentation and Graphics:                            Judging off the tutorial alone, you would assume that this game would actually be a competent single player. (Its not.) However it seems the groundwork has been set for it.  The lore is kinda interesting and all the characters seem quite interesting. (or at least interesting paradodies.)  Dwarves walk on stilts, elves are beauty queen models right up their grotesque faces. The arenas themselves are all gorgeous as well and invoke an interesting world. What I didn't like----- Repetitiveness                      Granted, because this is a multiplayer lobby shooter/fighter, you cannot expect too much variety. However it can begin to feel grindy quite quickly. A lot of the battles just begin to feel the same a few hours in, especially since most of the maps have the same objective. Grinding for levels and exp can be quite slow as well, so you may feel quite a drag unless you fork over some real money to expedite everything.Verdict: Give the game a try if you want some casual fun, but do not expect too much.  The game aspires to be an esport and the ground work is definately there, but will players stick around for everything else? I don't know.

content:
er 26, 2013
												Ten hours into this game and level 6, All that can really be said is it's a pay2win specially at lower levels. This game tries to be a parody of fanatasy and it does well on that orcs leaping across the map elfs freezing entrie parties to change the course of the battle, and other fun moments.Trying not to take it self very serious the gameplay at first childish picks up on some maps and later levels to being pure fun while working as a team, although most maps are as simple as run to the middle hold it for as long as possible. Back to the childish feel of the gameplay even though you will have a few spells that can knock your enemy back or down your basic attacks will be about as fun to watch as swinging it at the air since they don't do anything, but lower the HP of said enemy not even stoping them from swinging.For a game that tries to parody the fantasy world your left feeling like the market place is taking it to serious I mean every thing in this game can be bought with RL cash even leveling. This can turn alot of people away, but all and all it's got plenty of fun for a weekend run maybe a little more if you can clan up and find some good people to play with. I don't really need to say much on the graphics since they speak for themself in the screen shots it's a pretty game even if moving around seems blocky at times.I'd give it a 6.5/10 it does have some redeeming aspects.

number of helpful: 7 of 11 people (64%) found this review helpful
content:
2, 2016
												Seemingly hidden among the more popular online games, Panzar with it's refreshing fantasy landscapes, solid combat and well-crafted classes remind me of a golden era when pc games were made by experienced developers, artisans of the industry. There are premium cash shop that offers items for slight stats boosts and faster leveling, but the gameplay is designed around actual experience in playing to be good at it. Knowing when to swing your club and when to block as a berserker matters more than having more regen or power. Just like knowing which skill to use on which teammate as the paladin matters more than having more energy. The many setbacks in the game's promotion, mainly the excessive negativity in the reviews do restrict the game's community to be mainly of Russian players, where the game is from. Which is unfortunate seeing as Panzar is a beautiful game that deserves more spotlight. I hope this game do well and the developer continues to build it's world. It might help the pc games industry return to it's glorious days.82/100

												It's a Team Based PVP oriented game set up in a typical F2P format where players can grind to earn what they want or simply pay for it. The cash shop sells a variety of items such as cosmetics, level ups, crafting materials & potions. Currently the only game modes available are Capture Point, King of The Hill & Domination. There is a lack of a server list & choice of game mode so you won't know what game mode or map you'll be getting into until you start playing. Several different maps are available & range from small, medium & large & all hold up to 20 players or 10v10.

er 3, 2013
												Started playing it about a week before it hit steam, was really in need of a pvp game, forums brought me here. Panzar did and is doing the job. Can't tell for how long but so far I'm enjoying it. You could see it as a mix of Team Fortress, Mediaval Warfare and Tera. You choose a class, lvl doing pvp, no pve at all, gain levels, put stat points in talent tree, craft gear, lvl some more, unlock more abilities, but all while pvping in.There is no pve in here so don't lose you time if its what you want, but if you want some solid fighting in a Warhammer atsmosphere, try this game.Finally, about pay 2 win, bof, more like pay to progress, a la LoL. Yes you can do everything faster if you pay, but whats the point really, unless you only care about reaching the cap asap. For casuals, even lvl 1ish will be fun.Enjoy.

												How to Make Blue Velvet Smurf CupcakesIngredients: • 1 ½ cups sugar• 2  ½ cups all-purpose flour• 1 teaspoon vanilla extract• 1 cup buttermilk• 2 teaspoons blue gel paste food color• 1 ½ cups vegetable oil• 2 tablespoons cocoa powder• 2 teaspoons white vinegar• 1 ½ teaspoons baking soda• ½ teaspoon salt• 2 eggs• white and blue buttercream (buttercream video: 


YouTube™ Video:  

			Views: 0		



 • candy eyesProcedure:The first step is to make the Blue Velvet cupcakes.Combine flour, salt, and cocoa powder in a small bowl.  Set aside for later.  In a stand mixer, combine the oil, sugar, vanilla, eggs, and gel paste.  Mix until combined.  Add half of your flour mixture into the oil mixture, stirring on low.  Add half of the buttermilk.  Repeat until all the flour and milk is gone and mixture is combined completely.  With mixer on low speed, in a small separate bowl, combine baking soda and vinegar, and quickly add to batter, allowing the mixer to mix for about 10 more seconds.  This will make the batter light and fluffy.   Using a cookie scoop, fill cupcake liners 2/3 full, and bake at 350F for 20 minutes.  Allow to cool to room temperature.Prepare buttercreams (white and blue).  Using an round open tip, pipe a blue swirl onto the top of the cupcake.  Then, using a round open tip, slowly build up the white buttercream to a point, shaping it like the Smurf hat.  Add a nose with the blue buttercream by squeezing a small dot onto the blue base of icing.  Add the candy eyes. Happy Baking 10/10

content:
er 27, 2013
												Nice surprise, this title. Panzar is a very fun title right out of the box, the paid options basically seem to be 'shortcuts', which I've got no problem with. The progression, even without the paid options, is very satisfying and hasn't frustrated me just yet. The battles take place on some of the best multiplayer maps I've experienced, and while there are by my estimate, fewer than a dozen maps, the variables within each make each battle play out uniquely. The classes are varied, and they all have their place and fill their niche nicely. There's certainly something for everyone here, whatever your playstyle may be. While it does have its share of minor bugs, I've not encountered anything gamebreaking as of yet. The matchmaking during non-primetime hours can get very long and tiresome, leading to many players constantly re-rolling new characters to keep in the common levels 1-3 bracket. I sense that as this game has more time and exposure on steam, some of these matchmaking issues will clear up.Especially for the 'price', I highly recommend, one of the best F2P titles I've played.

If you plan to put mages in the game, make them worthy opponent otherwise remove them entirely. Also, remake your payment model to something more descent.

content:
er 26, 2013
												2 hours in, and I already feel like I'm in for a SUPER LONG grind if I want to get anything just by playing. Even with supporting my char with real cash. Good graphics is the only good thing here. Animations are strange, sluggish, slow [just jump, you will see lol], combat has ZERO impact to it, weak and boring sound effects make it even worse. Managed to get to lvl 3 before I had enought mats to craft single lvl 1 item for my char. And crafting takes 30 minutes, so I can only imagine how long it takes for higher lvl items. I don't even feel like writing more about this game, coz it's just a waste of time. Well, at least it works and looks good.Finally - imo World of Warcraft battlegrounds deserve 8/10, so this game if compared to them is like 3/10. Maybe 4/10 if you'r willing to spend some money on it. Grind / waiting game is HUGE here. Unless you are ready to pay extra for every single action/option/item/gold... you name it. Good Luck and have fun if that's your thing, I'm uninstalling now.

												I find it funny that the majority of people not recommending this game played less than 1 hour. Obviously they spent a lot of time in game checking out the full crafting system and playing multiple games and leveling up their characters. The first couple of levels are "boring" because its giving you the ground work so you dont get smoked later. Listen... you can call the game P2W... while there is a grind everything in the game can be earned as apposed to paid for. Then again the western market for F2P is horrible with the screaming of P2W..:EDIT:.additionally... i dont believe they've put up any North America servers yet. so some of the "issues" are due to NA players playing on Europe servers

y 31, 2014
												It's not the best game out there, but in general the simplicity of the game makes it easy to learn and it is fast-paced enough that it remains interesting for a decent period of time. Admittedly there are inherent flaws in the design and it does favor players who are willing to contribute to the game monetarily but that's to be expected from any free game -- after all, designers and programmers and customer support etc., etc. have to earn their keep too.There are some solid ideas behind the gameplay despite the problems Panzar has with balancing, and so on and so forth, that provide a good foundation. Most of the other issues are smaller fixes that could, with time and effort, be adjusted and "fixed." If they aren't, then the game isn't worth any serious commitment, but if their staff decides to amp up their game, no pun intended, then maybe playing wouldn't feel like such a waste of time.

content:
er 3, 2013
												I'm a veteran of this game from before it was released on Steam. Most of the negative reviews for this game are coming from people who have only played the game on steam and have under an hour on record, not exactly people who's opinion I would trust.Now for the actual review: The good;+The game looks visually stunning, it's running on the Cryengine and is one of the most graphically pleasing and atmospheric games available. The terrain and characters are flawlessly animated, the models are excellently rendered and the particle effects are magnificent. However the more technologically minded among you may be wondering "if it looks so good it must have hardware limitations and optimisation issues". Well, not that I can tell. The graphic scaling options allow the game to run on my current PC (I5+HD7950) as well as it does on my five year old PC, just not at the same quality. As for optimisation I can say that, even with the fact that Troxit (the developer, I believe) are a reasonably small operation, they have pulled out all the stops for optimisation, even big budget games like (Battlefield 4 for example) would be envious of the optimisation work that has gone into this game, it runs flawlessly on all of my rigs.+Variety of game modes. The amount of game modes available and the objectives range from the obvious capture and hold game mode to the simple capture point gauntlet and the simple closed in arena archetype. However there are several truly intriguing game modes along the lines of castle defence and siege game-play. One map involves a team attacking the gate of a castle, breaking in, opening the gates for your allies, securing a safe foothold and then making a stab at the centre of the castle after using a mechanism to raise the final capture point. The variety of game modes here really adds to the flavour of the game and the map designs clearly show an attention to detail on the part of the artistic team.+Each map has several of its own context sensitive items and mechanics. From slingshots to launch you onto an objective to a siege ramp that allows you to lay siege to a castle. I thoroughly enjoy messing around with these mechanics and finding a way to use them to the best effect. My current favourite trick is to run towards a group of enemies on my dwarf with an explosive barrel in hand and then laugh as the enemy players scurry for dear life. This may not seem like much to some but for me it adds a much needed feeling to the game that other multiplayer games lack.-----------+Classes are so diverse that there is enough here for everyone. Tanks, I have a question for you. Do you like playing a tank? Great, a position just opened up, have fun getting in the enemies face and showing them the value of orcish durability. You may need someone to support you, to pick you up when you're feeling down, to protect you with nothing more than pure faith (and magic). These men are known only as... PALADINS! Do you have a fascination with incense burners and helping incredibly reckless allies to not die within seconds of making contact with the enemy? Great, we could use someone like you. Just avoid huffing too much incense during battle, it's bad for your health kind of like.... A sister of fire! Are you someone who wants to watch the world burn? Do you find yourself wishing you could cause large fireballs to land on small people? This role is for you! Please just watch where you aim, fire isn't the most precise weapon in existence, no that would be... The blades of an INQUISITOR! Hide in the shadows, watch and wait in silence as your enemies health dwindles and then ATTACK while yelling "Nobody expects the inquisition!"(Optional but satisfying). Yes the inquisitor is everything you want in a bloodthirsty, puritanical murderer. Your enemies will not see you coming as they feel your blades plunge into their back.  Sapper: "Great, you died! Well don't just stand there!" Get on the sappers teleporter and go back to the fight! Yes, the sapper. A devious creature so well equipped for battle that having one of them at your back is enough to give you the support you need to win any battle. Place traps, build energy replenishing totems and then your greatest creation, a high powered mortar launcher that can turn an invading force into nothing but a charred hole in the battlefield.  Maybe you like the idea of being a sapper but want to play a more active role? Well the GUNNER class may have what you need. Lay down heavy support fire with your portable heavy machine gun station and let the enemy know that your name is the lord as they're ripped to shreds in a volly of high calibre rounds. All these explosions and fire may sound fun but don't you wish you could cool things down some times? Like...right down...to freezing? The ICE WITCH can do just that for you, the ability to freeze an entire enemy force solid for several seconds leaving them at the mercy of the TRUE lord of the battlefield...THE BERSERKER! No. Nobody is bigger, nobody is stronger, and you can be sure that nobody is DUMB ENOUGH to stand head to head with this barbarous monster. Where the others such as the inquisitor find refuge in the shadows and the gunner depends on range to protect him the BERSERKER! only knows one thing. A dead enemy is not a threat. Smash the stupidity out of any enemy that dares to stand in your way. The berserker waits club in hand for a day when he meets an enemy will be able to withstand his  sheer might. That day is not coming soon.-----------+An actual progression system! This game comes with a progression system that some may not like, but for the most part it functions as it should. You can get better gear, skills and abilities while levelling up and feel like you're working towards something. There's nothing that you can get with money that you cannot get with some effort and in game currencies.ALRIGHT! That's what's great about the game. I know there's a lot to digest, the game IS free so you should try it if nothing else. But let's get our books in order and we can do that by talking about the bad. No game is perfect...Maybe Tropico 4 (check it out, shameless plug).-The business model. It's a game, games are there to make money. It is perfectly possible, but costly, that you can buy your way to max level with the in game "level up for money" feature. While this does NOT convey a direct game play advantage you cannot deny that leveling with real world currency is tempting for those that enjoy the game (I know some reviewers just like to poke holes in games without being constructive but eff all that, I like to help so I'm going to make some suggestions!) I think that the leveling system should be altered somewhat. First of all reduce the leveling threshold. It's kind of frustrating to win a battle only see your progress bar go up 1/15th of a level. Secondly change the level purchasing system. Make it so you can only buy a level after you have at least filled your bar half way or more, to reduce the effectiveness of just buying levels.-Crafting. Right now crafting is annoying. But you new players...you have NO IDEA. A few months ago, even, the crafting system was much worse. just get rid of it and let us buy armour and weapons with IN GAME CURRENCY!-Balance. It's kind of difficult to enjoy the Berserker double tap of doom, speed up Control Recovery after stuns and knockdowns and freeze abilities. I would cut loss of control abilities effects by a big amount.Well it seems that the character limit has caught up with me. I could go on for several pages but here's the point I want to make:Don't let these naysayers put you off of the game, just give it a try, it's free after all.

content:
er 5, 2013
												This a wonderful game being buried by idiots. You get 5 gems every time you level in this game and by level 5 you can get the recruit pack which gives you premium for 7 days and a bunch of runes. Which is all you need to put yourself on a level playing field. After that if you are still playing the game after that maybe you should cough up some money? Most of the people disliking the game haven't even played an hour. With all that said the game matches you with people who are relatively near you in levels and power. So if you just buy a bunch of levels and gear you aren't going to be just beating up level 1 people for fun. Really you will be up against better people then you because they will know how to actually play. ANYWAY. The game basically plays like a mix of WoW and TF 2, the classes are all useful and fairly interesting. Though some are abit better then others. The game is just gorgeous and it runs well on high end systems which is more then I could say for crysis 3. The castle siege maps in particular are quite epic with devasting cannons and catapaults that can launch you over the defenders walls. Think objective mode in chivalry, or the assault maps from UT. If you ever wanted a good fantasy pvp action game this is most certainly it.

content:
er 5, 2013
												This game is incredibly fun. The entire concept is based around teamwork and how well you and your teammates can effectively plan or work together. The best games are when both sides do this effectively, leading to huge brawls over a control point that can last for minutes.General Gameplay: ( 9/10 ) Some classes could use a bit of tweaking in terms of fairness, but the overall class balance is nice.Graphics: ( 10/10) Beautiful graphics and a gorgeous arena on every map, not to mention certain maps have awesome features. One example is a wintery map has a blizzard every so often and makes visibility practically 0, making it hard for both teams to fight coherently.Fighting Mechanics: ( 7/10) Could use some improvement, but it includes a working block system, power attack/regular attack combo and every class has atleast 2 ways to attack, one from melee and one from range.Map Mechanics: ( 10/10 ) I have not found a game that has unique map interfaces like this one. If you're sieging a castle, you can work with your team to build siege ladders to get to the control point and defenders can destroy them. Or you can put up gates and barricades to slow attackers down for a while and give yourself not only a bit of breathing room, but a more manageable way to fight the enemy and maintain control.Multiplayer: ( 5/10 ) The reason this score is low is solely because the game is -entirely- PvP. There is no such thing as PvE for joking around with friends - only the cold, harsh battleground. Another deduction is from the game's seeming 'pay to win' at later levels - instead of having to farm gear, players could simply buy the highest tier gear. Even if it is availible to everyone, it would certainly give them a bit of advantage.
